. Originally a peninsula connected to the rest of the country by the Isthmus of Corinth, it is now cut off from the mainland by the narrow Corinth Canal, spanned by bridges connecting Peloponnese to

The Peloponnese administrative region covers most of the Peloponnese peninsula, except for the northwestern subregions of Achaea and Elis which belong to West Greece and a small portion of the Argolid peninsula that is part of Attica. The Pelopponese region itself is divided into five regional units:
, Argolis, Corinthia, Laconia and Messenia, which are further subdivided into 26 municipalities.

value: a quiet resort, with very good hotels, a beach and a casino.
- a nondescript port town. Can serve as a base for Mycenae. Some miles away the ancient Corinth, with the ruins of one of the first civilizations of Greece
- Pretty nondescript city. Main point of arrival for ferries from Italy and Ionian islands.
-  A nice town in the centre of Kyparissian Gulf.
- Very picturesque city in the southwest. Many French-style buildings, as well as a marina and a gloriously shady square.

- A seaside town south of Pylos. Its main feature is a spectacularly positioned and well preserved castle, which contains both Venetian and Ottoman elements. The town itself is also pleasingly old, and there is a small but delightful beach near the castle.

-  About 30 minutes drive further on from Finikounda is Koroni, a fishing village which snuggles beneath its great Venetian fortress that overlooks the beautiful harbourfront with pavement cafes and fish restaurants with fresh local produce and authentic Greek cuisine. Just before Koroni is the beautiful Zaga unspoilt beach and beyond are many other beaches.
- Main city of Messinia Province. Famous for its olives but also a pleasant city with an attractive seafront and stylish new marina.
- A village very close to Aigio.
, a typical town of the area, hosting interesting ancient and Byzantine monuments.
- The center of the administrative area, the third biggest.

- This historic city has a population of 10,000. It has two main arteries which make navigation really easy. To the west of the City is the beautiful, rugged Mt. Taygetos. The Byzantine city of Mystras is a short 15 minute ride away. This has relics worthy of a visit. There is a museum in Sparta housing some artifacts.
- A small fishing village. Nice seafood restaurants with plenty of beaches in the area mostly frequented by locals. Nearby
is a large limestone cave system which is toured on a boat.  Here you will find the point where Helen of Troy is said to have started the Trojan War. "The woman who launched a thousand ships."
â€” one of the oldest cities of Europe, Argos boasts some ancient ruins including an amphitheater, as well as a medieval castle
- A good base to explore surrounding area which includes
, a pictoresque seaside village, nearby one of the most famous ancient theaters.  Catch an ancient play in the summertime.
, a typical well preserved old town of the area
, a small (population approx. 300), beautiful village, combining sea and mountains. Ideal for mountain ramblers.
- The Rock of Gibraltar of Greece.  Really pretty with an ancient walled city.

- Today, the village has developed into a well-organised tourist resort with all the necessary comforts, as taverns, apartments, cafe-bars and nice beaches. Family hotel Irida Resort in Paralia, is a cultural oasis in kalo Nero's most successful tourism resort.

- An exceptionally pretty fishing village near Pylos in the Southwest. There are a couple of nice hotels to stay in, as well as an excellent campsite. The village also boasts several fine eateries, none of which are too expensive.
- A smaller town about 10 minutes drive from Methoni. It is a little more touristy, but does offer wonderful beaches and some nice tavernas.
- the cradle of the Greek independence revolution, surrounded by beautiful villages and historic sites.
- the southeastern tip of continental Europe, one of the most harsh places of Peloponnese during historic times, now hosting many interesting villages, views and beaches.

You will get along with English pretty well, in the more touristy places you won't have too much problems with German or Italian either. Pick up some

As in whole of Greece, almost all speak from some words to quite fluent English, as it is taught in public schools. Since Greeks travel frequently abroad for education or work and also they love foreign languages, there are many speakers of other languages also, usually French, Italian, German, Russian, some less frequently Spanish.

value: , by car or bus; having a car allows occasional stops that are worth along the way to most parts of Peloponnese.  Nafplio is a 2hr ride, Sparta about 4hrs,  Patras about 2,5, Kalamata about 3 hr 45 mins (3 hrs on the nonstop express bus).

value: Ancient Corinth. The relics of the famous town where St Paul lived and taught for quite some time. Nearby is the castle of Acrocorinthos and the opposing Penteskoyfi.
: The first olympic games were in Olympia in honor of Zeus.
: From the hill on which the palace was located one can see across the Argolid to the Saronic Gulf.
- Ancient theatre : A small city (polis) in ancient Greece, at the Saronic Gulf. One of the greatest ancient theatres in the world.

Corinth Canal : The builders dug the canal through the Isthmus at sea level. It is 6.3 kilometres (3.9 mi) in length and was built between 1881 and 1893.
Diros Cave, near the homonym town in Mani, Laconia, Greece.
Ladon River : Rivers were personified and credited with wooing nymphs and human maidens and fathering children.
hours=Apr: Sun 12AM-6PM; May, Oct: Sat, Sun 12AM-6PM; Jun-Sep: Tue-Sun 10AM-6PM. Closed Dec-Mar
Any of the locally produced traditional culinary products
Komboloi (worry beads), the best being in Nafplio.
Ceramics and sculptures from Atelier Sud art gallery near Finikounda. Inventive and evocative work by two very talented artists.
"Psistaria" or "Souvla" (meaning broiled food in general and also the broiling apparatus)
Loukaniko (regional sausage with orange) from the South area
Kokoras Krasatos / Kokoras Horiatikos (rooster in wine sauce/country cooked rooster)
Gida vrasti (goat stew), from the northeast area.

Any of the local production of Olives (specially southwest), Grapes(specially northeast) and Oranges(specially northeast).

Other typical Greek foods, such as:
Horiatiki Salata (Mixed salad), Tyri Saganaki (fried cheese), Kokkinisto (tomato sauce stew), Tyropitakia(cheese pies), Souvlaki, Pastitsio (pasta in the oven), Gemista (stuffed vegetables) etc.

value: Mavrodafni, sweet dark red wine in the Patras area

In general Greece is quite a safe place to visit, although the notorious dangers can be found here as well: Pickpockets in the cities and larger towns and drunk fellow-tourists at nighttime.
